BasicDescription.Title: Through The Night
BasicDescription.Synopsis: Jonathan Swain plays pieces by Mozart, Schuber, Pachelbel, JC Bach, JM Bach, Chopin, Bruckner, Sasnauskas, Telemann, Handel, Weill, Wagenaar, Mendelssohn, Sullivan, Corelli and Debussy.

With Jonathan Swain
12.05am Mozart: Violin Concerto No.4 in D major (K.218) Netherlands Radio Philharmonic Orchestra Guido Ajmone Marsan (conductor)
12.30am Schubert: Symphony No.3 in D major Saarbrucken Radio Symphony Orchestra Marcello Viotti (conductor)

4.35am Johan Wagenaar: Frithjofs Meerfahrt Netherlands Radio Symphony Orchestra Jac van Steen (conductor)
4.50am Mendelssohn(arr. Anon): On wings of song Hyun-Gon Kim (clarinet) Chi-Ho Cho (piano)

5.10am Corelli: Concerto Grosso in F major The Kings Consort Robert King (director)

5.35am Uro Prevorek: Spanish Dance Dejan Bravnicar (violin) Slovenian Radio & Television SO/Samo Hubad

BasicDescription.Title: Morning On 3
BasicDescription.Synopsis: Penny Gore plays Respighi's The Birds, Haydn's Joke Quartet, Mozart's Serenata Notturna, Brahms' Variations on a Theme by Haydn, Kabalevsky's Colas Breugnon and Elgar's Cockaigne.

Presented by Penny Gore
6.00am Respighi: The Birds I Solisti Veneti Claudio Scimone (conductor)
6.30am Haydn: String Quartet in E flat, Op.33 No.2 The Joke The Lindsays
7.00am Mozart: Serenata Notturna, K239 Concentus Musicus Wien Nikolaus Harnoncourt (conductor)
7.40am Brahms: Variations on a theme by Haydn, Op.56a Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra Claudio Abbado (conductor)
8.00am Kabalevsky: Colas Breugnon - Overture Russian National Orchestra Mikhail Pletnev (conductor)
8.30am Elgar: Cockaigne (In London Town) Philharmonia Orchestra Sir John Barbirolli (conductor)

BasicDescription.Title: Composer Of The Week
BasicDescription.Synopsis: Max Bruch (1838-1920): Donald Macleod introduces music by Max Bruch including Jubilate, Amen, Septet in E flat, Piano Trio, Op 5 (Finale), String Quartet No 2 and Violin Concerto No 1.

Max Bruch (1838-1920)
Bruch is primarily known for just one work, his Violin Concerto. During this week of programmes, Donald Macleod explores the composer's life, and the rest of this prominent German composer's output. Bruch chose to live and move in a time-warp, and was not the sort of personality to adapt to the new world of Debussy and Stravinsky.
Jubilate, Amen Cheryl Studer (soprano) Ambrosian Singers London Symphony Orchestra
Septet in E flat major, (1st movement) Consortium Classicum Dieter Kl�cker
Piano Trio in C minor (Finale) G�bel Trio
String Quartet no 2 in E Major (3rd movement) ISOS Quartett
Violin Concerto no 1 in G minor Kyung-Wha Chung (violin) The London Philharmonic Klaus Tennstedt

BasicDescription.Title: CD Masters
BasicDescription.Synopsis: Rob Cowan plays Handel's Alleluja, Sibelius' Violin Concerto in D minor, Flotow's Martha, Lully's Armide and Les Amants Magnifiques, and Grieg's Symphony.

With Rob Cowan
Handel: Alleuja Erna Berger (soprano) Michael Raucheisen (piano)
Sibelius:Violin Concerto in D minor, Op. 47 Jascha Heifetz (violin) Leopold Stokowski (conductor)
Flotow: "Nancy! Julia! Verweile Letzte Rose, wie magst du so einsam hier bluhn?" (Martha, Act II) Erna Berger (soprano) Peter Anders (tenor) Staatskapelle Berlin Johannes Sch�ler (conductor)
Lully: Passacaille; Prelude (Armide) Entr�e dApollon (Les amants magnifiques) Musica Antiqua, Koln Reinhard Goebel (director)
Grieg: Symphony in C minor, CW112 Norwegian Radio Orchestra Ari Rasilainen (conductor)

BasicDescription.Title: Morning Performance
BasicDescription.Synopsis: Tommy Pearson talks to pianist Joanna MacGregor and plays some of her BBC recordings. Music is by Moses Molelekwa, Bach, Nancarrow, Ives, Django Bates, Cage, Cowell and Lou Harrison.

Artist in Focus: Joanna MacGregor
Tommy Pearson talks to the pianist, composer, promoter, record label boss, and tireless enthusiast about her musical passions, illustrated with live recordings from the BBC archives.
JS Bach: Contrapunctus II (The Art of Fugue)
Conlon Nancarrow: Study for player piano no. 6
Charles Ives: 3-page sonata
Joanna MacGregor (piano)
Django Bates: Underfelt
Conlon Nancarrow: Prelude [1935]
Django Bates: Sequential Circuits
Human Chain: Django Bates Iain Ballamy (keyboards) Stuart Hall (bass), Martin France (drums) Joanna MacGregor (piano)
John Cage: Sonatas and interludes nos. 14, 15 Henry Cowell (Aeolian harp)
The Snows of Mt Fujiyama Joanna MacGregor (piano)
Lou Harrison: Piano Concerto BBC Philharmonic Joanna MacGregor (piano) Charles Bornstein (conductor)

BasicDescription.Title: Lunchtime Concert
BasicDescription.Synopsis: Schubert's Octet in F, played by the Gaudier Ensemble, direct from the Wigmore Hall. Presented by Fiona Talkington.

BasicDescription.Title: BBC Orchestras
BasicDescription.Synopsis: The BBC Philharmonic play Mendelssohn's Fingal's Cave, Chopin's Piano Concerto No 1, Mendelssohn's Midsummer Night's Dream, Hindemith's Symphonic Metamorphosis and Bartok's Miraculous Mandarin.

BBC Philharmonic In Wiesbaden
The first in a week of concerts recorded in Germany, a popular destination this year for the BBC orchestras. Today, the BBC Philharmonic and conductor Marin Alsop are in the elegant spa town of Wiesbaden on the banks of the Rhine. Presented by Tommy Pearson.
Mendelssohn: Overture, The Hebrides Chopin: Piano Concerto no. 1 Mendelssohn: Scherzo, Nocture & Wedding March from A Midsummer Nights Dream Marin Alsop (conductor) Ewa Kupiec (piano)
Hindemith: Symphonic Metamorphosis of themes by Carl Maria von Weber Yan Pascal Tortelier (conductor)
Bartok: Miraculous Mandarin, Suite Marin Alsop (conductor)

BasicDescription.Title: Stage And Screen
BasicDescription.Synopsis: Edward Seckerson pays tribute to Jerome Kern - the first genius of Broadway.

BasicDescription.Title: In Tune
BasicDescription.Synopsis: Sean Rafferty presents a selection of music, plus news from the arts world. Email: in.tune@bbc.co.uk

BasicDescription.Title: Performance On 3
BasicDescription.Synopsis: Wigmore Hall Gala Concert: Includes Schubert and Wolf sung by Angelika Kirchschlager with Julius Drake, and two cycles sung by Ian Bostridge with Mitsuko Uchida and Britten's Winter Words.

Wigmore Hall Gala Concert
Stephanie Hughes presents the first concert in the Directors Festival which marks William Lyne's final season after 36 years as Artistic Director of Wigmore Hall
Schubert: 3 Ellen Songs D 837-9 Wolf: 4 Mignon Songs (Goethe Lieder) Schubert: St�ndchen, D 920
Angelika Kirchschlager (mezzo soprano) Royal College of Music Male Chorus Julius Drake (piano)
Schumann: Liederkreis, Op 39 Britten: Winter Words, Op 52
Ian Bostridge (tenor) Mitsuko Uchida (piano)

BasicDescription.Title: Night Waves
BasicDescription.Synopsis: Richard Coles recalls the impact of Noel Coward's play The Vortex, which opens tomorrow at the Donmar Warehouse in a new production by Michael Grandage.

Noel Coward's play exploring the darker side of the upper classes, The Vortex, caused a sensation when it premiered in 1924 and made him an overnight star.
On the the eve of Michael Grandage's new production at the Donmar Warehouse, Richard Coles and guests revisit the impact of the play at the time.

BasicDescription.Title: Late Junction
BasicDescription.Synopsis: Verity Sharp presents an eclectic mix of late-night listening, includling 1970s Estonian pop and folk group Collage and a recent piece for strings by Arvo Part.
Verity Sharp with another week of unusual sounds and unexpected combinations, including a recording of 1970s Estonian pop and folk group Collage, and a recent piece for string orchestra by Arvo P�
